projectDesc.p: This text is prepared as part of the Literature in Context project, which provides an accessible, curated, edited, and marked-up selection of primary sources relevant to the study and the teaching of British and American literature of the 17th, 18th, and 19th centuries. This project is funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities and developed by faculty at The University of Virginia and Marymount University.

interpretation.p: Research informing these annotations draws on publicly-accessible resources, with links provided where possible. Annotations have also included common knowledge, defined as information that can be found in multiple reliable sources. If you notice an error in these annotations, please contact lic.open.anthology@gmail.com.

normalization.p: Original spelling and capitalization is retained, though the long s has been silently modernized and ligatured forms are not encoded.

hyphenation.p: Hyphenation has not been retained, except where necessary for the sense of the word.

segmentation.p: Page breaks have been retained. Catchwords, signatures, and running headers have not.

lg.l: Stout RomulusRomulus is the founder of Rome and son of Mars in Roman Mythology., Remus was the brother of Romulus. They disputed over where to settle Rome, which eventually led to the murder of Remus. Source: WikipediaRemus Founder, and fast
King

Whom vestall RheaRhea is the mother of the twins Romulus and Remus. And she is a "vestal virgin" or one of the priestesses who were in charge of the sacred fire in the Vesta Temple. Source: Oxford English Dictionary and Wikipedia, into th' world did
bring
His father was not MarsMars is the god of war and a depicted as a Military General., as some devis'd
But Aemulus(Draft) I can't figure out who this is, in Armour all disguis'd
Thus, he deceiv'd his Neece, she might not know
The double injury(Draft) what is this double injury, he then did doe:
Where she heards once had Coats, and Sheep their
Folds,
Where SwainesCountrymen, farmers, and shepherds. Source: Oxford English Dictionary, and rustick Peasants and made their
Holds
A Citty Faire did Romulus erect:
The Mistris of the World, eachrespect
His Brother Remus there, by him was slaineThis is the origin of Rome's name as Romulus had the city take his name.,
For leaping o're the Walls with some disdaine
The Stones at first was cimented with blood
And bloody hath it prov'd, since Erst it flood
This City built, and Sacrifices done,
A formed of Government he next begun;
A hundred Senators he likewise chose
And with the stile of Patres honour'd those
His City to replenish, men he wants
Great priveleges then, to all he grants,
That wil within these strong built walls reside,
And this new gentle Government abide:
Of Wives there was so great scarcity,
They to their neighbors sue, for a supply;
But all disdaine alliance then to make,
So Romulus was forc'd this course to take
Great shewes he makes at Tilt, and TurnamentTilt and Tournament refers to races held on foot, chariot and horses to prove ones' worthiness. Source: The Illustrated History of Rome,477,
To see these sports, the SabinsSabines were an italic tribe from the mountainous region near the east of the Tiber River. Source: Oxford English Dictionary are bent;
Their Daughters by the Romans then were caught,
Foe to recover them, a Feild was fought;
But in the end, to finall peace they come,
And Sabins, and one people, dwelt in Rome.
The Romulus now more potent 'gin to grow,
And FedinatesFedinates are the citizens of Fidenae. Source: Wikipedia they wholly over-throw:
But Romulus then comes unto his end,
Some faiining say, to heav'n he did ascend;
Others, the leven and thirtyeth of his reigne
Affirme, that by the Senate he was slaine.
Numa Pompilius
Numa Pompilius, is next chosen King,
Held for his Piety, some sacred thing;
To JanusGod of doorways in Roman religion. Source: Encyclopedia Brittanica, he that famous Temple built,
Kept shut in peace, but ope when blood was spilt
The Religious Rites and Customs instituted,
And Priests and FlaminesFlamines are priests dedicated specifically to one deity. Source: Wikipedia likewise he deputed,
Their AugursAn Augur is a religious position that observed the surroundings such as animals to understand the people's standings with the Gods. strange, their gestures and attire,
And vestal maids to keep the holy fire.
The Nymph AegeriaAegeria is the Latin goddess of knowledge and healing. this to him told,
So to deludeMake people believe that false things are true. Source: Oxford English Dictionary the people he was bold:
Forty three years he rul'd with general praise,
Accounted for a God in after dayes.
Tullius Hoftilius
Tulius Hoftilius, was third Roman King,
Who Martial Discipline in use did bring;

War with the ancient AlbansThe inhabitants of Alba Longa, a city in ancient Latium. Latium was a western state on what is now Italy. Source: Oxford English Dictionary and WikipediaAlbans he doth wage,
The strife to end, fix Brothers doe ingage;
Three call'd HoratiiThe Horatii were triplet warriors of the Roman Empire., on Romans side;

And CuriatiiThe Curiatii are triplets from Alba Longa. They fought against the Horatii. The Curiatii managed to kill all but one of the Horatii, Publius. Publius however, managed to use logic and planning to defeat all three of the Curiatii by himself and win the war for Rome. Source: Wikipedia, three Albans provide;
The Romans Conquereth, others yeeld the day,
Yet for their compact, after false the play
The Romans fore incens'd, their Generall slay,
And from old Alba fetch the wealth away;
Of Latin Kings this was long since the Seat,
But now demolished, to make Rome great.
Thirty two years did Tullius reign, then dye,
Left Rome in wealth, and power still growing high.
Ancus Martius
Next Ancus Martius sits upon the Throne,
Nephew unto Pomphilius dead, and gone;
Rome he inlarg'd, new built againe the wall,
Much stronger, and more beautifull withall:
A stately Bridge he over TyberThe Tyber River runs through Rome. made,
Of Boats, and Oares, no more they need the aide;
Faire Oftia(DRAFT) what or who is this? Was this a long s that just got translated as an "f" he built, this Town, it flood,
Close by the mouth of famous Tyber flood:
Twenty foure yeare, th' time of his royall race,
Then unto death unwillingly gives place.
Tarquinius Prifcus
Tarquin, a Greek, at Corinth borne, and bred,
Who soe seditionRebeliously. Source: Oxford English Dictioanry from his Country fled;
Is entertain'd at Rome, and in short time,
By wealth, and favour, doth to honour climbe;
He after Martius death the Kingdome had,
A hundred Senatours he more did adde;
Warres with the Latins he againe renewes,
And Nations twelve, of Tuscany subdues:
To such rude triumphs, as young Rome then had,
Much state, and glory, did this PiscusA great Roman diplomat. Source: Wikipedia adde:
Thirty eight yeares (this Stranger borne) did reigne,
And after all, by Ancus Sons was slaine.
Servius Tullius
Next, Servius Tullius fits upon the Throne,
Ascends not up, by merits of his owne.
But by the favour, and the speciall grace
Of Tanquil, Late Queen, obtaines the place;
He ranks the people, into each degree,
As wealth had made them of abilitie;
A generall Mufter takes, which by account,
To eighty thousand soules then did amount:
Forty foure yeares did Servius Tullius reigne,
And then by Tarquin, Prifcus Son, was slaine.
Tarquinius Superbus, the last Roman King.
Tarquin the proud, from manners called so,
Sate on his Throne, when he had slaine his foe
Sixtus his Son, doth (most unworthily)
Lucretia force, mirrour of chastety;
She loathed so the fact, she loath'd her life,
And fled her guiltless blood, with guilty knife
Her Husband sore incens'd, to quit this wrong,
With Junius Brutus rose, and being strong,
The Targuins they from Rome with speed expell,
In banishment perpetuall, to dwell;
The Government they change, a new one bring,
And people sweat, ne're to accept of King.
The end of the Roman Monarchy
being the fourth and last.
